forkee.name: ZeroTierOne
forkee.description: A Smart Ethernet Switch for Earth

issue.title: How to use CLI directly in Android via TUN
issue.body:
As ZerotierOne Android is not open source, I wanted to be able to use Zerotier via the CLI, so I did some experimentation.

I statically compiled the ARM executable via the cross-compilation toolchain and ran it on an Android 10 device (**using root**) with the following compilation parameters.

```
    make \
    ZT_STATIC=1 \
    ZT_DEBUG=1 \
    ZT_DEBUG_TRACE=1 \
    CC=arm-none-linux-gnueabihf-gcc \
    CXX=arm-none-linux-gnueabihf-g++ \
    CFLAGS="-Wall" \
    CXXFLAGS="-Wall" \
    LDFLAGS="-s" \
```

I then discovered that although the Android device was visible in the Zerotier Controller and the IP and version were correctly displayed, the corresponding IP and routing table was correctly displayed on the device via `ip ad` and `ip route`. However, it was not actually possible to communicate.

This log output is available on Android:

```
requesting configuration for network <NETWORK_ID>
learned new path 47.254.39.171/9993 to 451e1bcd2d (packet 83c94f7455245fc1 local socket 24751240 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 47.254.39.171/9993 to 451e1bcd2d (packet 27f78687dc532c4c local socket 24752072 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 47.254.39.171/9993 to 451e1bcd2d (packet 3aace22563cf24c1 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 84.17.53.155/9993 to cafe04eba9 (packet 6206803e3b771efa local socket 24751240 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 50.7.252.138/9993 to 62f865ae71 (packet 62067fb9b5119d9a local socket 24752072 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 104.194.8.134/9993 to cafe9efeb9 (packet 62965da8502523c5 local socket 24751240 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path 104.194.8.134/9993 to cafe9efeb9 (packet 62965da85025b36f verb 5 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
requesting configuration for network <NETWORK_ID>
learned new path 103.195.103.66/9993 to 778cde7190 (packet 624f26cab7985461 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path <MY_ID>/30356 to f4b7f79a0a (packet 5fd54282b47ffaab verb 8 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path <MY_ID>/30356 to f4b7f79a0a (packet 9350ccb5c20f1429 verb 8 local socket 24751240 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path <MY_ID>/30356 to f4b7f79a0a (packet b7cb5f1fc6e0c571 verb 8 local socket 24752072 network 0000000000000000)
learned new path 84.17.53.155/9993 to cafe04eba9 (packet 6206803e3bb32355 local socket 24752072 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path 104.194.8.134/9993 to cafe9efeb9 (packet 62965da85094d197 verb 5 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path 104.194.8.134/9993 to cafe9efeb9 (packet 62965da850bbe285 verb 5 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path <MY_ID>/30356 to f4b7f79a0a (packet 2592f42b345e677b verb 8 local socket 24761048 network 0000000000000000)
trying unknown path <MY_ID>/30356 to f4b7f79a0a (packet c3430f29f87d3b50 verb 8 local socket 24751240 network 0000000000000000)
```

I checked the [AOSP code][1] and found no significant differences from Zerotier.

I'm not sure if it has anything to do with [this method][2], which is [called here at NDK][3].

[1]:https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/+/master:frameworks/base/services/core/jni/com_android_server_connectivity_Vpn.cpp;l=58;drc=38898882788358f6ae26de987e1346597366d2f7
[2]:https://developer.android.com/reference/android/net/VpnService#protect(int)
[3]:https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/+/master:system/netd/client/NetdClient.cpp;l=490;drc=422de9d1d0e325ccd4e911c6c446d2feb1f7c33a

comment.body:
Thank you again @cinit , it was indeed a cheap mistake on my part, and as per your guidelines, the Zerotier is now working fine.

Also I changed some code in ZT and now it works without me having to set the `ip` command manually.

forkee.name: ZeroTierOne
forkee.description: A Smart Ethernet Switch for Earth

issue.title: Unable to connect from a network that blocks ICMP packages
issue.body:
I have physical network **A**, **B**, **C**, all of which have public IPv6 addresses. Network **B** blocks all ICMP packages.

In network **A** and **C**, my device can connect to zerotier without problem.

In network **B**, my device cannot connect to zerotier:
if the device just switched from **A** to **B**, the desktop UI report status OK, but ZeroTier Central says it is not online;
if I restart zerotier service in network **B**, the desktop UI report status REQUEST_CONFIGURATION, forever. This is seen on version _1.10.6_ and _1.12.2_.

When I downgrade to _1.4.6_, the device becomes **able** to connect to zerotier.

I guess the problem is about ICMP because I saw the firewall rule and I know network **B** blocks ICMP (e.g. you can't ping anything).
I also guess that zerotier has changed its way to connect to a way that uses ICMP from a specific version, before which it had a way different from ICMP.

I want to know which the specific version is, and I hope that you can add a fallback way to connect.

comment.body:
Thanks for reporting. I think the ICMP part might be a "red herring". We haven't heard similar and 1.4.6 was many years ago. So there may be some other factor in network B's firewall. ZeroTier uses only UDP. Unless no connection to anything can be made, then it falls back to TCP. 

It does sound like something is getting stuck in a buggy way though. 

https://github.com/zerotier/ZeroTierOne/tree/main/tcp-proxy might help

comment.body:
Hi @Lua12138.
It seems you are mistakenly using rule preferences as table ids.
The range [10000, 32000] is for rule preferences, not table ids.
Please read [ip-rule manual](https://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/focal/en/man8/ip-rule.8.html) carefully.

comment.body:
Thank you @cinit  very much for your reply.

But after I tried each table id separately, I still couldn't connect. Which table id should I choose?

I tried every table id with this:

```ash
i=10000
while [ $i -le 32000 ]
do
  echo "table id:$i"
  ip route add table $i 10.0.1.0/24 dev ztyvvzal2p proto kernel scope link
  sleep 60s
  ip route del table $i 10.0.1.0/24 dev ztyvvzal2p proto kernel scope link
  i=`expr $i + 1000`
done

```

issue.title: After inactive time, ping and RDP to remote Windows computer do not work via Zerotier
issue.body:
Zerotier Windows client version: 1.10.6

If there is no connection to the Windows computer for a long time (more than 6 hours), the connection is lost through Zerotier. Neither ping nor RDP works. This is solved by connecting with Teamviewer, AnyDesk or OpenVPN to the remote computer. As a connection is established with another program, Zerotier starts pinging and RDP.
It feels like Zerotier falls asleep and then suddenly wakes up. At the same time, ping to RDP to this computer works on the local network, but does not work on the Zerotier network. Zerotier is just starting to work by connecting to the computer in a different way. This has been observed on several different Windows 10 computers.

[3]:https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/+/master:system/netd/client/NetdClient.cpp;l=490;drc=422de9d1d0e325ccd4e911c6c446d2feb1f7c33a

comment.body:
Hi @Lua12138, sorry for my late and unsolicited comment. I have been using zerotier-one CLI on Android with root privilege for several days and I hope my comment will be helpful for those who want to run ZeroTier on Android with root, typically for running alone with other privilege tunnels or joining multiple networks.

Android uses the routing policy database (RPDB) to route the application's IP packets. It has its own routing policy and it doesn't rely on the traditional main route table (whose table ID is 254). You can check that by running the `ip rule` and `ip route show table all` commands. If you are not familiar with iproute2, you may want to read https://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/focal/en/man8/ip-rule.8.html.

As you mentioned above, the `VpnService.protect(int fd)` method sets a correct fwmark on a socket, such that the socket will bypass a VPN tunnel. If you are not using zerotier-one together with other VpnService, you do not need to call `VpnService.protect(int fd)`, because there are no other VPN tunnels.

When zerotier-one starts with root privilege on Android, it will create TAP tunnels, connect to planets and other peers, and set an IP address on its interface, except add a rule into the routing policy database, and that's all you need to do when you try to run ZeroTier CLI on Android.

The routing rule preference constants used by the Android system can be found at https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/main/+/main:system/netd/server/RouteController.h and you can check whether it's consistent with the output of the `ip rule` command on your Android. After that, pick a route table to add the ZeroTier TAP interface into it by `ip route add table $your_selected_table_id $cide/$prefix dev $zt_iface_name proto kernel scope link` and ZeroTier should work on your Android now.

issue.title: ZeroTier does not work on Ubuntu 22.04 Jammy (error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1)
issue.body:
- What you expect to be happening.
  ZeroTier should work : )
- What is actually happening?
  It doesn't.
- Any steps to reproduce the error.
  - Install ZeroTier
  - `zerotier-cli --help`:
    `zerotier-cli: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`
- Any relevant console output or screenshots.
  - `journalctl -b -u zerotier-one`:
    ```
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop systemd[1]: Started ZeroTier One.
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop zerotier-one[122674]: /usr/sbin/zerotier-one: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop systemd[1]: zerotier-one.service: Main process exited, code=exited, status=127/n/a
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop systemd[1]: zerotier-one.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'.
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop systemd[1]: zerotier-one.service: Scheduled restart job, restart counter is at 1.
    Apr 29 03:37:34 x-laptop systemd[1]: Stopped ZeroTier One.
    ```
  - `sudo find /usr -mount -type f -name "libssl*" | apt-file find -lf - | xargs apt list --installed`:
    ```
    Listing... Done
    android-libboringssl/jammy,now 10.0.0+r36-1 amd64 [installed,automatic]
    libnss3/jammy,now 2:3.68.2-0ubuntu1 amd64 [installed,automatic]
    libssl3/jammy,now 3.0.2-0ubuntu1 amd64 [installed,automatic]
    libssl3/jammy,now 3.0.2-0ubuntu1 i386 [installed,automatic]
    ```
  - Trying to downgrade: `sudo apt install zerotier-one=1.8.7`:
    ```
    Reading package lists... Done
    Building dependency tree... Done
    Reading state information... Done
    Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
    requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
    distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
    or been moved out of Incoming.
    The following information may help to resolve the situation:

    The following packages have unmet dependencies:
    zerotier-one : Depends: libssl1.1 (>= 1.1.1) but it is not installable
    E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
    ```
- What operating system and ZeroTier version. Please try the latest ZeroTier release. 
  - `apt list '~i ~nzerotier'`:
    ```
    Listing... Done
    zerotier-one/focal,now 1.8.9 amd64 [installed]
    ```
  - `lsb_release -ird`:
    ```
    Distributor ID: Ubuntu
    Description:    Ubuntu 22.04 LTS
    Release:        22.04
    ```

#1575 is probably related

comment.body:
I had the same issue on Ubuntu 23.10 server edition. I got it to work by:
1. Uninstall zerotier
2. Install libssl1.1 deb package.
3. Re-install zerotier and all was okay.
```
wget http://nz2.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/o/openssl/libssl1.1_1.1.1f-1ubuntu2.19_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i libssl1.1_1.1.1f-1ubuntu2.19_amd64.deb
```

issue.title: [Feature Request] Orbit moon on android and ios devices.
issue.body:
We're in a mobile-first world now and having feature parity for mobile devices and desktop devices means a lot.

I think this feature is a great feature just for the above reasons.

issue.title: [Feature Request] Ability to disable metrics.prom write
issue.body:
https://discuss.zerotier.com/t/ability-to-disable-on-disk-metrics-prom-file/15420

I am a Windows user and tmpfs is not really an option for me. I am willing to open a PR for this, but I would like to discuss how a toggle would be enabled. AFAIK, there is no configuration file for global behavior so there is not a straight forward way of implementing this

One elegant way in my opinion would be to check if `metrics.prom` exists on program start. If it does, the metric logging is enabled

Let me know what you think

comment.body: nevermind, I found the other configuration. I guess that would be enough. Should I add an option and submit a PR?

One elegant way in my opinion would be to check if `metrics.prom` exists on program start. If it does, the metric logging is enabled

Let me know what you think
